To display the entire dataset, you can use pandas' DataFrame.to_string() method or reset the index.


# Option 1: Display all rows and columns
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
print(df.to_string())

# Option 2: Show all data with a cleaner format
df.reset_index(drop=True, inplace=True)
print(df)

To show the first 35 rows of your DataFrame, you can use pandas' head() function with a parameter specifying how many rows to display. Here's the code:


df.head(35)


This will return the first 35 rows of your DataFrame.

Alternatively, if you prefer using slicing notation:

df[:35]


Both methods achieve the same result but use different syntax styles.

To show the full dataset, you can use either of these two concise methods:

1. Using DataFrame's built-in method:
```python
print(df.to_string())
```

2. Using a built-in function for display (requires IPython):
```python
from IPython.display import display
display(df)
```

Both will output the entire DataFrame without truncation.
